original_conversation.content: God, my hands are still shaking. [exhausted] Look at them—I can't even hold my coffee steady. [shaky voice] Three hundred thousand tons. That's what we just brought through. The Empress Marie, biggest container ship the company's ever handled, and we took her through that... that absolute monster of a storm. [long pause] I keep thinking about that moment when the wind hit sixty knots and she started to drift. [anxious] For a second there, I thought— [sigh] I mean, the channel's only four hundred meters wide at Devil's Point. [very quietly] We had maybe thirty meters of clearance on either side. With those swells coming in sideways, it was like, um... like trying to thread a needle while someone's shaking the table. [relieved] But she responded. God, she responded beautifully when I called for emergency thrust. [proudly] Twenty-three years I've been doing this job. [pause] Twenty-three years, and I've never felt anything like that. [slowly] The captain, he just looked at me when we cleared the point. [chuckle] Didn't say a word, just nodded. [warmly] But his face said everything. [extremely happy] We did it. We actually did it. [deep pitch] Everyone's safe, ship's intact, and I just— [trailing off] I think I need to sit down for a minute.

subject: Your harbor pilot expertise just guided the largest ship in company history safely through a dangerous storm
